traffic_visible_response: Collective Memory 集体记忆 is an important concept in social psychology which was first fully articulated by French sociologist Maurice Halbwachs in It refers to the process and result of a specific social group s members sharing past events Specifically Collective Memory can be defined as follows Shared Recollection It is not a simple summation of individual memories of group members but a common memory of the group s past constructed based on shared cultural tools It is not an objective reproduction of the past but a reconstruction of the past based on the present Cultural Identity It is closely related to cultural identity Enhancing national cultural identity must precede enhancing subcultural identity Individual cultural identity first recognizes the national and ethnic culture followed by subcultures Dynamic and Reconstruction Collective Memory is not static The English terms collective memory and collective remembering are distinguished with the former referring more to a static knowledge base and the latter more to the reconstruction of past representations a process often highly controversial Forms and Media Collective memories can take various forms such as being materialized and fixed through texts and monumental buildings The concept has been further developed by scholars like Jan Assmann and Paul Connerton In summary Collective Memory represents a shared constructed and transmitted memory among group members based on their shared cultural tools and experiences It is dynamic involving continuous reconstruction and various forms of expression Please note that this explanation is for educational purposes and does not constitute professional advice in the fields of psychology or sociology
